Back: The study of living organisms.
The basic unit of life.

Front: What are the main parts of an animal cell?
Back: Nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria and ribosomes.

Front: What are the main parts of a plant cell?
Back: Nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria, ribosomes, cell wall, vacuole and chloroplasts.

Front: What is the function of the nucleus?
Back: Controls cell activities and contains DNA.

Front: What does the cell membrane do?
Back: Controls what enters and leaves the cell.

Front: What is the function of cytoplasm?
Back: Where most chemical reactions happen.

Front: What is the function of mitochondria?
Back: Site of aerobic respiration.

Front: What is the function of ribosomes?
Back: Site of protein synthesis.

Front: What is the function of chloroplasts?
Back: Absorb light for photosynthesis.

Front: What is the function of the cell wall?
Back: Supports and strengthens plant cells.

Front: What is the function of the vacuole?
Back: Contains cell sap and helps keep the cell rigid.
Movement of particles from high concentration to low concentration.
Concentration gradient, temperature and surface area.
Movement of water from high to low water concentration through a partially permeable membrane.
Movement against a concentration gradient using energy.

Front: Why do cells need active transport?
Back: To absorb substances when concentration is lower outside the cell.
Cell division that produces two identical cells.
Growth, repair and asexual reproduction.
When a cell becomes specialised for a job.
In early stages of an organism’s life.
An unspecialised cell that can develop into different cell types.
Embryos and adult bone marrow.
A group of similar cells working together.
A group of different tissues working together.
A group of organs working together.
A system that transports substances in the blood.

Front: What is the function of the heart?
Back: Pumps blood around the body.
Blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart.
Blood vessels that carry blood towards the heart.
Tiny vessels where exchange of substances happens.
Liquid that carries cells and dissolved substances.

Front: What do red blood cells do?
Back: Carry oxygen using haemoglobin.

Front: How are red blood cells adapted?
Back: Biconcave shape and no nucleus for more haemoglobin.

Front: What do white blood cells do?
Back: Defend the body against pathogens.
Help blood clot to stop bleeding.
A microorganism that causes disease.

Front: What types of pathogens are there?
Back: Bacteria, viruses, fungi and protists.
A disease that can be spread between organisms.
By air, water, direct contact or vectors.
An organism that carries a pathogen between hosts.
A substance that stimulates the immune system to produce antibodies.
The ability to resist a disease.
Killing bacteria or stopping them reproducing.

Front: Why do antibiotics not work on viruses?
Back: Viruses live inside cells and are not bacteria.
When bacteria survive antibiotics and pass on resistant genes.

Front: What is a non communicable disease?
Back: A disease that cannot be spread between people.

Front: Name examples of non communicable disease.
Back: Heart disease, cancer and type 2 diabetes.
A biological catalyst.
They control reaction rates in living things.
An enzyme changes shape and stops working.
Temperature, pH and substrate concentration.
The temperature where the enzyme works fastest.
Breaking down large insoluble molecules into small soluble ones.

Front: What is the role of the stomach?
Back: Produces acid and protease enzymes.

Front: What is the role of the small intestine?
Back: Completes digestion and absorbs nutrients.

Front: How is the small intestine adapted for absorption?
Back: Large surface area with villi and good blood supply.
Respiration that uses oxygen to release energy.

Front: What is the word equation for aerobic respiration?
Back: Glucose plus oxygen produces carbon dioxide and water.

Front: What is anaerobic respiration in animals?
Back: Respiration without oxygen producing lactic acid.

Front: What is anaerobic respiration in plants and yeast?
Back: Glucose produces ethanol and carbon dioxide.
Process plants use to make glucose using light.

Front: What is the word equation for photosynthesis?
Back: Carbon dioxide plus water produces glucose and oxygen.
Absorbs light energy.
Light intensity, carbon dioxide concentration and temperature.
The factor that stops the rate increasing further.
A diagram showing feeding relationships.
An organism that makes its own food by photosynthesis.
An organism that eats plants or animals.
An organism that breaks down dead material.
Many interconnected food chains.
All the organisms and the environment in an area.
The variety of different species in an ecosystem.
It helps ecosystems stay stable and resilient.
Large scale removal of trees.
It destroys habitats.
Increase in Earth’s average temperature.
A gas that traps heat, such as carbon dioxide or methane.

Front: How do greenhouse gases cause warming?
Back: They absorb and re emit infrared radiation.
Movement of water between sea, air and land.
Liquid water becomes water vapour.
Water vapour becomes liquid droplets.
Water falling as rain, snow or hail.
Water vapour released from plant leaves.
Breakdown of dead organisms by microorganisms.
Warm temperatures, oxygen and moisture.
Maintaining stable internal conditions.
Enzymes and cells work best in stable conditions.
A change in the environment.
A reaction to a stimulus.
System that detects stimuli and coordinates responses.
A rapid automatic response to a stimulus.
They protect the body from harm.
A chemical messenger carried in the blood.
A system of glands that produce hormones.
A section of DNA that codes for a protein.
A long coiled DNA molecule found in the nucleus.
Differences between individuals of the same species.
Genetic differences and environmental factors.
Better adapted organisms survive and reproduce more.
Change in species over time due to natural selection.
A molecule that carries genetic information.
A, T, C and G.
A pairs with T, C pairs with G.
Making proteins from DNA instructions.
Copying DNA into mRNA.
Building proteins from mRNA.
Choosing parents with desirable traits.
Changing an organism's DNA.
Producing genetically identical organisms.
A random change in DNA.
Cell division producing gametes.
Sex cells such as sperm and egg.
Fusion of male and female gametes.
Passing traits from parents to offspring.
An allele expressed if present.
An allele expressed only if two copies are present.
The genetic makeup of an organism.
The physical characteristics of an organism.

Front: What is a Punnett square used for?
Back: Predicting genetic outcomes.
Testing for genetic disorders.
Reduced gene pool.
Climate change, pollution and habitat loss.
Excess nutrients causing oxygen depletion.
Fertiliser runoff into water.

Front: What is transpiration rate affected by?
Back: Light, temperature, humidity and wind.

Front: What is the equation for photosynthesis in symbols?
Back: 6CO2 plus 6H2O produces C6H12O6 plus 6O2.

Front: What is the equation for aerobic respiration in symbols?
Back: C6H12O6 plus 6O2 produces 6CO2 plus 6H2O.

Front: What is a limiting factor in respiration?
Back: Availability of oxygen or glucose.
The speed of chemical reactions in the body.
Age, gender and activity level.
A hormone that lowers blood glucose.
A hormone that raises blood glucose.
The pancreas.
A condition where the pancreas produces little or no insulin.
A condition where body cells do not respond properly to insulin.
Insulin injections.
Diet control, exercise and sometimes medication.
Maintaining a constant body temperature.

Front: How does the body cool down?
Back: Sweating and increased blood flow to skin.

Front: How does the body warm up?
Back: Shivering and reduced blood flow to skin.
Widening of blood vessels near the skin.
Narrowing of blood vessels near the skin.

Front: What is the role of the kidneys?
Back: Filter waste from the blood.
Water, urea and salts.
A waste product formed in the liver from excess amino acids.
A treatment that filters blood artificially.
Movement of water up the plant due to evaporation.
Transport water and minerals in plants.
Transport sugars in plants.
Movement of sugars through the phloem.
A feeding position in a food chain.

Front: What happens to energy between trophic levels?
Back: Energy is lost as heat.
Total mass of living material.

Front: What is a pyramid of biomass?
Back: Diagram showing biomass at each trophic level.
Organisms competing for limited resources.

Front: What resources do plants compete for?
Back: Light, water, space and minerals.

Front: What resources do animals compete for?
Back: Food, territory and mates.
A feature that improves survival.
A physical feature that aids survival.
An action that helps survival.
An organism that lives in extreme conditions.

Front: What is a quadrat used for?
Back: Sampling plant populations.
Sampling without bias.
Release of harmful substances into environment.
Contamination of water sources.
Harmful gases in the atmosphere.
Protecting and managing natural resources.
Cutting down some trees only.
Breeding endangered species in controlled environments.
Range of different genes in a population.
It increases survival chances.
Humans selecting traits.
Producing identical plants from cuttings.
Growing plants from small tissue samples.
Keeping equipment sterile.
Identical antibodies produced from one cell.

Front: What are monoclonal antibodies used for?
Back: Pregnancy tests and targeted drugs.

Front: What is a pathogen entry point?
Back: A place where pathogens enter the body.
Body response causing redness and swelling.
White blood cells engulfing pathogens.
Proteins that target specific pathogens.
Molecules that trigger immune response.
Protection when most population is vaccinated.
Inactive substance used in trials.

Front: What is a double blind trial?
Back: Neither patient nor doctor knows who receives treatment.
Variable kept the same in an experiment.
Variable you change.
Variable you measure.
Getting consistent results.
Measuring what you intend to measure.
Group not receiving treatment.
Evaluation by other scientists.
Movement of carbon through living and non living systems.

Front: What is decomposition in carbon cycle?
Back: Release of carbon dioxide by decay.
Burning of fuels releasing carbon dioxide.
Amino acids.
Simple sugars.
Fatty acids and glycerol.
Controlling water balance.
Pathway taken by nerve impulses.
Gap between nerve cells.
Carries signal across synapse.

Front: What is reaction time affected by?
Back: Age and distractions.
Only certain substances can pass.
A plant cell full of water.
Plant cell losing water and shrinking.
Releasing energy for life processes.
Energy molecule in cells.
All chemical reactions in a cell.
Meeting needs without harming future generations.

Front: What is GCSE Biology exam tip?
Back: Define key terms clearly and apply them to context.
